Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
'Be a Scientist!' is a full-scale development project that examines the impact of a scalable, STEM afterschool program which trains engineers to develop and teach inquiry-based Family Science Workshops (FSWs) in underserved communities. This project builds on three years of FSWs which demonstrate improvements in participants' science interest, knowledge, and self-efficacy and tests the model for scale, breadth, and depth. The project partners include the Viterbi School of Engineering at the University of Southern California, the Albert Nerken Engineering Department at the Cooper Union, the Los Angeles Museum of Natural History, and the New York Hall of Science. The content emphasis is physics and engineering and includes topics such as aerodynamics, animal locomotion, automotive engineering, biomechanics, computer architecture, optics, sensors, and transformers.

The project targets underserved youth in grades 1-5 in Los Angeles and New York, their parents, and engineering professionals. The design is grounded in motivation theory and is intended to foster participants' intrinsic motivation and self-direction while the comprehensive design takes into account the cultural, social, and intellectual needs of diverse families. The science activities are provided in a series of Family Science Workshops which take place in afterschool programs in eight partner schools in Los Angeles and at the New York Hall of Science in New York City. The FSWs are taught by undergraduate and graduate engineering students with support from practicing engineers who serve as mentors. The primary project deliverable is a five-year longitudinal evaluation designed to assess (1) the impact of intensive training for engineering professionals who deliver family science activities in community settings and (2) families' interest in and understanding of science. Additional project deliverables include a 16-week training program for engineering professionals, 20 physics-based workshops and lesson plans, Family Science Workshops (40 in LA and 5 in NY), a Parent Leadership Program and social networking site, and 5 science training videos. This project will reach nearly one thousand students, parents, and student engineers.

The multi-method evaluation will be conducted by the Center for Children and Technology at the Education Development Center. The evaluation questions are as follows: Are activities such as recruitment, training, and FSWs aligned with the project's goals? What is the impact on families' interest in and understanding of science? What is the impact on engineers' communication skills and perspectives about their work? Is the project scalable and able to produce effective technology tools and develop long-term partnerships with schools? Stage 1 begins with the creation of a logic model by stakeholders and the collection of baseline data on families' STEM experiences and knowledge. Stage 2 includes the collection of formative evaluation data over four years on recruitment, training, co-teaching by informal educators, curriculum development, FSWs, and Parent Leadership Program implementation. Finally, a summative evaluation addresses how well the project met the goals associated with improving families' understanding of science, family involvement, social networking, longitudinal impact, and scalability.

A comprehensive dissemination plan extends the project's broader impacts in the museum, engineering, evaluation, and education professional communities through publications, conference presentations, as well as web 2.0 tools such as blogs, YouTube, an online social networking forum for parents, and websites. 'Be a Scientist!' advances the field through the development and evaluation of a model for sustained STEM learning experiences that helps informal science education organizations broaden participation, foster collaborations between universities and informal science education organizations, increase STEM-based social capital in underserved communities, identify factors that develop sustained interest in STEM, and empower parents to co-invest and sustain a STEM program in their communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of Iridescent’s Be A Scientist! grant was to connect families from under-resourced communities in Los Angeles and New York City with young STEM professionals. We successfully achieved the three goals that we identified in our original proposal. These three goals were:

1) recruit a more diverse audience into STEM,

2) enable participants to develop a deeper understanding of scientific practice, and

3) assess long-term impact on participants.  

Over the course of five years, the program engaged 2,173 children and parents, exceeding our expectation of 1,700 participants. The total contact hours for this program over five years was 18,628. There were a total of 259 Family Science sessions and these were taught by 127 trained engineering students.

Each course consisted of 5 sessions held over the course of 5 weeks, held in partnership with eight different Los Angeles public schools as well as the Los Angeles Natural History Museum (NHM) and the New York Hall of Science (NYSCI). Over 90% of participants for this project were considered underserved and attended Title 1 schools in LA and NY. Throughout the project, we saw a steady increase in our participation and retention rate. In year 5, 54% of participants were returning for a second or third time.

Key Findings

The Education Development Center’s (EDC) Center for Children and Technology led the formative and summative evaluation of this project starting in year one. At the end of this grant, we received a summative evaluation report highlighting the success and impact of our program on the participants and also a recommendation on what to improve in future programs. Our results show that our model of engagement works in underserved communities and demonstrates clear, positive impacts on children and parents.

Impact on Students

Students participating in the program were interested in and engaged in science and engineering related activities both in and outside of school. They indicated that participating in the Family Science program had a positive impact on their knowledge, attitudes, and behaviors. The vast majority of students indicated that they understood science and engineering better (90%), and that they had a better understanding of what jobs were available in those fields (88%). They also responded that they were more excited about doing challenging activities (94%), and that they were more interested in their science classes at school (86%). They reported being more engaged in practices of scientific thinking, such as persistence (89%) and questioning (79%).

Impact on Parents and Families

The parents and family members of the students who participated in the Family Science program reported being highing engaged in their children’s schools. They overwhelmingly reported positive changes in their own behavior since participating. Over 93% of all respondents agreed or strongly agreed that, since participating in the program, they would engage in more science-related activities and doing hands-on science activities at home. Similarly, 94% indicated that they would ask their child more questions about science class, and 91% said they would encourage their child to pursue an education or career in science or engineering. 92% of parents indicated that they themselves understand science and engineering better, and 89% said they are more interested in these content areas.

Impact on Engineering Students

An overwhelming majority of the undergraduate engineering students reported having a positive experience in the program. They enjoyed working together, co-facilitating the workshops, and engaging in meaningful interactions with students and families. Most of the engineers (80%) reported that since participating in this program, they felt more comfortable managing a classroom and they felt more proficient working with children. 75% of them also reported improved communication skills, specifically public speaking and communicating complex science and engineering ideas to non-scientific audiences.

Intellectual Merit

Through Be a Scientist, we were able to successfully create a scalable informal science education program for underserved communities across the country. This project ultimately led to the creation of a technical communication course for engineers as well as a series of parent training modules that empower parents to support their child in STEM learning.

Broader Impacts

Be a Scientist! was a program that connected two disparate groups of people-underserved minority families and engineers. Through training engineers to become role models and mentors, we helped make science relevant and applicable to families’ everyday lives. Families gained a deeper understanding of physics and engineering concepts and also developed critical-thinking and problem-solving skills, curiosity, creativity, perseverance, and perhaps most importantly, a strong sense of self-efficacy.

These traits are crucial to ultimately earning a degree and launching a career in STEM fields and ultimately contribute to a broader workforce that can tackle any difficult challenge, particularly in technical fields like engineering. Through connecting children from underserved backgrounds with relatable role models from STEM industries, we inspired and empowered children to pursue careers they may never thought were possible.
